entry.title: 3.Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

Given a string s, find the length of the longest substring without repeating characters.

Example 1:
Input: s = â€œabcabcbbâ€
Output: 3
Explanation: The answer is â€œabcâ€, with the length of 3.

Example 2:
Input: s = â€œbbbbbâ€
Output: 1
Explanation: The answer is â€œbâ€, with the length of 1.

Example 3:
Input: s = â€œpwwkewâ€
Output: 3
Explanation: The answer is â€œwkeâ€, with the length of 3.
Notice that the answer must be a substring, â€œpwkeâ€ is a subsequence and not a substring.

Example 4:
Input: s = â€œâ€
Output: 0

Constraints:
0 <= s.length <= 5 * 104
s consists of English letters, digits, symbols and spaces.

æˆ‘çš„è§£æ³•

è§£é¢˜æ€è·¯

æ‰¾åˆ°å­—ç¬¦ä¸²çš„æœ€é•¿æ— é‡å¤å­—ç¬¦çš„å­ä¸²ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨æ»‘åŠ¨çª—å£æ¥è®°å½•å½“å‰å­—ä¸²å­˜åœ¨çš„å­—ç¬¦ï¼ŒåŠå…¶æ•°é‡ã€‚å¦‚æœå½“å‰æ²¡æœ‰é‡å¤çš„å­—ç¬¦ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆåæŒ‡é’ˆå°±å¾€åç§»åŠ¨ï¼Œå¦‚æœæœ‰ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆå°±å°†å‰æŒ‡é’ˆå¾€åç§»åŠ¨ã€‚

å®ç°ä»£ç

entry.title: 704.Binary Search
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

Given an array of integers nums which is sorted in ascending order, and an integer target, write a function to search target in nums. If target exists, then return its index. Otherwise, return -1.

You must write an algorithm with O(log n) runtime complexity.

Example 1:
Input: nums = [-1,0,3,5,9,12], target = 9
Output: 4
Explanation: 9 exists in nums and its index is 4

Example 2:
Input: nums = [-1,0,3,5,9,12], target = 2
Output: -1
Explanation: 2 does not exist in nums so return -1

æˆ‘çš„è§£æ³•

å®ç°ä»£ç

entry.title: 72.Edit Distance
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

Given two strings word1 and word2, return the minimum number of operations required to convert word1 to word2.

You have the following three operations permitted on a word:

Insert a character
Delete a character
Replace a character

Example 1:
Input: word1 = â€œhorseâ€, word2 = â€œrosâ€
Output: 3
Explanation:
horse -> rorse (replace â€˜hâ€™ with â€˜râ€™)
rorse -> rose (remove â€˜râ€™)
rose -> ros (remove â€˜eâ€™)

Example 2:
Input: word1 = â€œintentionâ€, word2 = â€œexecutionâ€
Output: 5
Explanation:
intention -> inention (remove â€˜tâ€™)
inention -> enention (replace â€˜iâ€™ with â€˜eâ€™)
enention -> exention (replace â€˜nâ€™ with â€˜xâ€™)
exention -> exection (replace â€˜nâ€™ with â€˜câ€™)
exection -> execution (insert â€˜uâ€™)

æˆ‘çš„è§£æ³•

è§£é¢˜æ€è·¯

æ²¡æƒ³åˆ°é¢è¯•é‡Œä¸Šæ¥å°±æ¥äº†ä¸€é“hardé¢˜ç›®ï¼Œå¥½åœ¨åœ¨æç¤ºä¸‹å†™å‡ºæ¥äº†å·®ä¸å¤šã€‚æœ€ä¸»è¦å°±æ˜¯çŠ¶æ€è½¬ç§»æ–¹ç¨‹ä»£è¡¨çš„æ„ä¹‰ï¼Œdp[i][j]ä»£è¡¨çš„æ˜¯word1å‰iä½è½¬æ¢ä¸ºword2å‰jä½éœ€è¦æœ€å°‘çš„æ­¥éª¤ã€‚

å®ç°ä»£ç

entry.title: 1018.Binary Prefix Divisble by 5
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

Given an array A of 0s and 1s, consider N_i: the i-th subarray from A[0] to A[i] interpreted as a binary number (from most-significant-bit to least-significant-bit.)

Return a list of booleans answer, where answer[i] is true if and only if N_i is divisible by 5.

Example 1:
Input: [0,1,1]
Output: [true,false,false]
Explanation:
The input numbers in binary are 0, 01, 011; which are 0, 1, and 3 in base-10. Only the first number is divisible by 5, so answer[0] is true.

Example 2:
Input: [1,1,1]
Output: [false,false,false]

Example 3:
Input: [0,1,1,1,1,1]
Output: [true,false,false,false,true,false]

Example 4:
Input: [1,1,1,0,1]
Output: [false,false,false,false,false]

æˆ‘çš„è§£æ³•

è§£é¢˜æ€è·¯

æƒ³æ³•æ˜¯ç”¨ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°æ¥è®°å½•å½“å‰æ•°å­—ï¼Œåˆ°ä¸‹ä¸€ä½æ—¶å°±å°†å…¶å·¦ç§»ä¸€ä½ï¼Œç„¶ååœ¨åŠ ä¸ŠAä¸­å¯¹åº”ä½ã€‚ä¸è¿‡æ•°å­—ä¼šè¶…å‡ºèŒƒå›´ï¼Œçœ‹äº†ä¸‹è®¨è®ºå‘ç°å¯ä»¥ç”¨å–10çš„æ¨¡æ¥é¿å…è¶Šç•Œï¼Œå› ä¸ºèƒ½è¢«5æ•´é™¤çš„æ•°åªéœ€è¦è€ƒè™‘æœ€åä¸€ä½æ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯5æˆ–0å³å¯ã€‚

å®ç°ä»£ç

entry.title: 116.Populating Next Right Pointer in Each Node
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

You are given a perfect binary tree where all leaves are on the same level, and every parent has two children. The binary tree has the following definition:

struct Node {
int val;
Node left;
Node right;
Node *next;
}
Populate each next pointer to point to its next right node. If there is no next right node, the next pointer should be set to NULL.

Initially, all next pointers are set to NULL.

Follow up:

You may only use constant extra space.
Recursive approach is fine, you may assume implicit stack space does not count as extra space for this problem.

æˆ‘çš„è§£æ³•

è§£é¢˜æ€è·¯

ä½¿ç”¨ä¸€ä¸ªé˜Ÿåˆ—æ¥è®°å½•ä¸€å±‚çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹ã€‚

å®ç°ä»£ç 

ä¸è¿‡è¿™æ ·ä½¿ç”¨çš„ç©ºé—´å°±æœ‰O(n)äº†ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸æ˜¯å¸¸é‡ç©ºé—´ã€‚å¯ä»¥ç”¨é€’å½’çš„æ–¹æ³•å°±ä¸éœ€è¦é¢å¤–çš„ç©ºé—´ã€‚

entry.title: 103.Binary Tree Zigzag Level Order Traversal
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

Given a binary tree, return the zigzag level order traversal of its nodesâ€™ values. (ie, from left to right, then right to left for the next level and alternate between).

For example:
Given binary tree [3,9,20,null,null,15,7],
3
/ \
9 20
/ \
15 7
return its zigzag level order traversal as:
[
[3],
[20,9],
[15,7]
]

æˆ‘çš„è§£æ³•

è§£é¢˜æ€è·¯

ä½¿ç”¨åŒå‘é˜Ÿåˆ—ï¼Œå¥‡æ•°è¡Œçš„ä»å·¦å¾€å³ï¼Œå¶æ•°è¡Œçš„ä»å³å¾€å·¦ã€‚

å®ç°ä»£ç

entry.title: 328.Odd Even Linked List
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

Given a singly linked list, group all odd nodes together followed by the even nodes. Please note here we are talking about the node number and not the value in the nodes.

You should try to do it in place. The program should run in O(1) space complexity and O(nodes) time complexity.

Example 1:
Input: 1->2->3->4->5->NULL
Output: 1->3->5->2->4->NULL

Example 2:
Input: 2->1->3->5->6->4->7->NULL
Output: 2->3->6->7->1->5->4->NULL

Constraints:
The relative order inside both the even and odd groups should remain as it was in the input.
The first node is considered odd, the second node even and so on â€¦
The length of the linked list is between [0, 10^4].

æˆ‘çš„è§£æ³•

è§£é¢˜æ€è·¯

å°†é“¾è¡¨çš„å¥‡æ•°èŠ‚ç‚¹æ”¾åˆ°å‰é¢ï¼Œå¶æ•°èŠ‚ç‚¹æ”¾åˆ°åé¢ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨åŸåœ°ç®—æ³•ã€‚

å®ç°ä»£ç

entry.title: 714.Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock With Transaction Fee
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

Your are given an array of integers prices, for which the i-th element is the price of a given stock on day i; and a non-negative integer fee representing a transaction fee.

You may complete as many transactions as you like, but you need to pay the transaction fee for each transaction. You may not buy more than 1 share of a stock at a time (ie. you must sell the stock share before you buy again.)

Return the maximum profit you can make.

Example 1:
Input: prices = [1, 3, 2, 8, 4, 9], fee = 2
Output: 8
Explanation: The maximum profit can be achieved by:
Buying at prices[0] = 1
Selling at prices[3] = 8
Buying at prices[4] = 4
Selling at prices[5] = 9
The total profit is ((8 - 1) - 2) + ((9 - 4) - 2) = 8.
Note:

0 < prices.length <= 50000.
0 < prices[i] < 50000.

æˆ‘çš„è§£æ³•

è§£é¢˜æ€è·¯

åŠ¨æ€è§„åˆ’ï¼šçŠ¶æ€ä¸ºå½“å‰çš„åˆ©æ¶¦ï¼Œåˆ†ä¸ºå½“å‰æŒæœ‰å’Œä¸æŒæœ‰ä¸¤ç§æƒ…å†µã€‚

å®ç°ä»£ç 

æ‰§è¡Œç”¨æ—¶ï¼š208 ms, åœ¨æ‰€æœ‰ C++ æäº¤ä¸­å‡»è´¥äº†80.02%çš„ç”¨æˆ·
å†…å­˜æ¶ˆè€—ï¼š55.4 MB, åœ¨æ‰€æœ‰ C++ æäº¤ä¸­å‡»è´¥äº†28.21%çš„ç”¨æˆ·

å¯ä»¥ä¸ç”¨æ•°ç»„æ¥åš

æ‰§è¡Œç”¨æ—¶ï¼š204 ms, åœ¨æ‰€æœ‰ C++ æäº¤ä¸­å‡»è´¥äº†84.78%çš„ç”¨æˆ·
å†…å­˜æ¶ˆè€—ï¼š50.9 MB, åœ¨æ‰€æœ‰ C++ æäº¤ä¸­å‡»è´¥äº†65.83%çš„ç”¨æˆ·

entry.title: 290.Word Pattern
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

Given a pattern and a string s, find if s follows the same pattern.

Here follow means a full match, such that there is a bijection between a letter in pattern and a non-empty word in s.

Example 1:
Input: pattern = â€œabbaâ€, s = â€œdog cat cat dogâ€
Output: true

Example 2:
Input: pattern = â€œabbaâ€, s = â€œdog cat cat fishâ€
Output: false

Example 3:
Input: pattern = â€œaaaaâ€, s = â€œdog cat cat dogâ€
Output: false

Example 4:
Input: pattern = â€œabbaâ€, s = â€œdog dog dog dogâ€
Output: false

Constraints:

1 <= pattern.length <= 300
pattern contains only lower-case English letters.
1 <= s.length <= 3000
s contains only lower-case English letters and spaces â€˜ â€˜.
s does not contain any leading or trailing spaces.
All the words in s are separated by a single space.
a w e

entry.title: 409.Longest Palindrome
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

Given a string s which consists of lowercase or uppercase letters, return the length of the longest palindrome that can be built with those letters.

Letters are case sensitive, for example, â€œAaâ€ is not considered a palindrome here.

Example 1:

Input: s = â€œabccccddâ€
Output: 7
Explanation:
One longest palindrome that can be built is â€œdccaccdâ€, whose length is 7.
Example 2:

Input: s = â€œaâ€
Output: 1
Example 3:

Input: s = â€œbbâ€
Output: 2

Constraints:

1 <= s.length <= 2000
s consits of lower-case and/or upper-case English letters only.

æˆ‘çš„è§£æ³•

entry.title: 49.Group Anagrams
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

Given an array of strings strs, group the anagrams together. You can return the answer in any order.

An Anagram is a word or phrase formed by rearranging the letters of a different word or phrase, typically using all the original letters exactly once.

Example 1:
Input: strs = [â€œeatâ€,â€teaâ€,â€tanâ€,â€ateâ€,â€natâ€,â€batâ€]
Output: [[â€œbatâ€],[â€œnatâ€,â€tanâ€],[â€œateâ€,â€eatâ€,â€teaâ€]]

Example 2:
Input: strs = [â€œâ€]
Output: [[â€œâ€]]

Example 3:
Input: strs = [â€œaâ€]
Output: [[â€œaâ€]]

Constraints:

1 <= strs.length <= 104
0 <= strs[i].length <= 100
strs[i] consists of lower-case English letters.

æˆ‘çš„è§£æ³•

è§£é¢˜æ€è·¯

ä¸å¤ªä¼šåšçš„ä¸€é¢˜ï¼Œçœ‹äº†ä¸‹é¢˜è§£ï¼Œå¯ä»¥ç”¨hashmapæ¥å­˜æ”¾æ•´ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ•°ç»„ï¼Œkeyæ˜¯ç»è¿‡æ’åºçš„stringï¼Œvalueæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ•°ç»„ï¼ŒåŒ…å«æ¥æ‰€æœ‰å½“å‰å­—æ¯ç»„åˆçš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ã€‚

å®ç°ä»£ç

entry.title: A860-Lemonade-Change
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

At a lemonade stand, each lemonade costs $5.

Customers are standing in a queue to buy from you, and order one at a time (in the order specified by bills).

Each customer will only buy one lemonade and pay with either a $5, $10, or $20 bill. You must provide the correct change to each customer, so that the net transaction is that the customer pays $5.

Note that you donâ€™t have any change in hand at first.

Return true if and only if you can provide every customer with correct change.

Example 1:
Input: [5,5,5,10,20]
Output: true
Explanation:
From the first 3 customers, we collect three $5 bills in order.
From the fourth customer, we collect a $10 bill and give back a $5.
From the fifth customer, we give a $10 bill and a $5 bill.
Since all customers got correct change, we output true.

Example 2:
Input: [5,5,10]
Output: true

Example 3:
Input: [10,10]
Output: false

Example 4:
Input: [5,5,10,10,20]
Output: false
Explanation:
From the first two customers in order, we collect two $5 bills.
For the next two customers in order, we collect a $10 bill and give back a $5 bill.
For the last customer, we canâ€™t give change of $15 back because we only have two $10 bills.
Since not every customer received correct change, the answer is false.

Note:
0 <= bills.length <= 10000
bills[i] will be either 5, 10, or 20.

æˆ‘çš„è§£æ³•

å®ç°ä»£ç

entry.title: 143.Reorder List
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

Given a singly linked list L: L0â†’L1â†’â€¦â†’Ln-1â†’Ln,
reorder it to: L0â†’Lnâ†’L1â†’Ln-1â†’L2â†’Ln-2â†’â€¦

You may not modify the values in the listâ€™s nodes, only nodes itself may be changed.

Example 1:
Given 1->2->3->4, reorder it to 1->4->2->3.

Example 2:
Given 1->2->3->4->5, reorder it to 1->5->2->4->3.

entry.title: 844.Backspace String Compare
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

Given two strings S and T, return if they are equal when both are typed into empty text editors. # means a backspace character.

Note that after backspacing an empty text, the text will continue empty.

Example 1:

Input: S = â€œab#câ€, T = â€œad#câ€
Output: true
Explanation: Both S and T become â€œacâ€.
Example 2:

Input: S = â€œab##â€, T = â€œc#d#â€
Output: true
Explanation: Both S and T become â€œâ€.
Example 3:

Input: S = â€œa##câ€, T = â€œ#a#câ€
Output: true
Explanation: Both S and T become â€œcâ€.
Example 4:

Input: S = â€œa#câ€, T = â€œbâ€
Output: false
Explanation: S becomes â€œcâ€ while T becomes â€œbâ€.
Note:

1 <= S.length <= 200
1 <= T.length <= 200
S and T only contain lowercase letters and â€˜#â€™ characters.
Follow up:

Can you solve it in O(N) time and O(1) space?

æˆ‘çš„è§£æ³•

å®ç°ä»£ç 

æ‰§è¡Œç”¨æ—¶ï¼š0 ms, åœ¨æ‰€æœ‰ C++ æäº¤ä¸­å‡»è´¥äº†100.00%çš„ç”¨æˆ·
å†…å­˜æ¶ˆè€—ï¼š6.4 MB, åœ¨æ‰€æœ‰ C++ æäº¤ä¸­å‡»è´¥äº†35.40%çš„ç”¨æˆ·

entry.title: 771.Jewels and Stones
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

Youâ€™re given strings J representing the types of stones that are jewels, and S representing the stones you have. Each character in S is a type of stone you have. You want to know how many of the stones you have are also jewels.

The letters in J are guaranteed distinct, and all characters in J and S are letters. Letters are case sensitive, so â€œaâ€ is considered a different type of stone from â€œAâ€.

Example 1:
Input: J = â€œaAâ€, S = â€œaAAbbbbâ€
Output: 3

Example 2:
Input: J = â€œzâ€, S = â€œZZâ€
Output: 0
Note:

S and J will consist of letters and have length at most 50.
The characters in J are distinct.

æˆ‘çš„è§£æ³•

è¿™é¢˜æ¯”è¾ƒç®€å•ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨ä¸€ä¸ªmapæ¥è®°å½•Sä¸­å­—ç¬¦å‡ºç°çš„æ¬¡æ•°ï¼Œç„¶åå†åœ¨mapé‡ŒæŸ¥æ‰¾æœ‰æ²¡æœ‰Jä¸­çš„å­—ç¬¦å‡ºç°ã€‚

å®ç°ä»£ç

å†…å­˜æ¶ˆè€—ï¼š6.2 MB, åœ¨æ‰€æœ‰ C++ æäº¤ä¸­å‡»è´¥äº†56.14%çš„ç”¨æˆ·
